user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarGetIdByName:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarGetIdByName(osal_id_t *var_id, const char *var_name)
{
    int32 return_code;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(var_id);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(var_name);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindByName(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_CONDVAR, var_name, var_id);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_CHECK_POINTER(var_id);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation as presented: the call OS_CHECK_POINTER(var_id) is a read-only check of the pointer parameter and does not modify the pointer itself. This conforms to Rule 17.8 (the object pointed-to may be modified, but the pointer shall not). Note: if the macro were implemented so that it assigns to or otherwise modifies the parameter (for example, '#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(p) ((p) = NULL)' or performing p = something), that would violate the rule. Verify the actual macro definition to be certain.
